titleStmt.title:
On a Damn'd
LETTER
OF ABUSE.
To the Reverend Doctor D────la────y.
Humbly proposed to the Consideration of the poor Author.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Facile est inventis addere. ··Vet. Adag.
WHAT Doctor, if great CARTERET Condescends 3}
To chat with S──t and you, as private Friends,

l.hi: Ans. Their Visits for the Favour, make amends.

lg.l: Must you so silly be, to tell the Town, 3}
And boast of Favours, he may blush to own?

l.hi: Ans. Was ever such a Piece of Nonsense known!

lg.l: Is this the Modest, Dutiful, Behaviour, 3}
You shew your Patron, for so great a Favour?

l.hi: Ans. Thy Muse is damn'd, and no Reprieve can save her.

lg.l: Think you, these Honours, to thy Merit due, 3}
What equal Honours can reflect from you?

l.hi: Ans. You wou'd not ask the Question, if you knew.

lg.l: You may, perhaps, propose Immortal Fame, 3}
Under the Shelter of your Patron's Name:
Ans. Great Maro with Augustus, did the same.
If you presume too far, you miss that end, 3}
For the like Course Sw──t lost his Gall's-town Friend.
Ans. That you may ne're have one to lose──God send.
And may in time disturb your Patron too, 3}
To see the simple choice he made, of you.

l.hi: Ans. To read your simple Stuff, wou'd make him spew.

lg.l: But is my Lord still short of his Intent, 4}
Or is thy Merit of that vast extent,
That nothing less than Thousands can Content?

l.hi: Ans. Whilst I, for lack of Farthings, Nonsense vent.

lg.l: There was a time when Paddy out of hope, 4}
Thought a West-Indian jaunt his utmost Scope;
Ans. There was a time when Johnny out of hope,
Ans. Fled to the Indies to avoid the Rope.
The World's well mended since with Patrick, now 3}
Nothing but Visto's, and Canals will do.

l.hi: Ans. 'Twere much more mended, if you honest grew.

lg.l: But pray, great Sir, what Friend of common Sense 3}
Wou'd labour to promote such vain Expence?

l.hi: Ans. While I, in Garret starve, for want of Pence.

lg.l: And must your Brethren all in Hamlets dwell, 3}
To adorn your Busts, and young St. Patrick's Cell?
Ans. Such Saints as you, are fit to People Hell.
Why may not some of them, for ought you know, 3}
Have a desire to build, or to bestow,
Ans. On John, a Gibbet for his Numbers low.
Retrench then, and be Modest, if you can Sir, 3}
Or raise Objections, stronger than your Answer,

l.hi: Ans. Retrench thy Vices, or you'll dye a Dancer.

lg.l: Think Doctor, after double Vicar, double Rector, 3}
A dignity in Christ-Church, City Lecture,

l.hi: Ans. Thou double Dunce, to slander thy Protector.

lg.l: And something else, which you have still forgot 3}
A College-place: Won't all this boil the Pot;

l.hi: Ans. Thou'lt ne'er be witty, whilst thy Head is hot.

lg.l: Then judge, how very aukwardly it looks, 3}
You have not yet enough, to buy you Books,
Ans. Thou get'st 'em cheaper──if we credit Br──ks.
Good Patrick, take Advice, and first read o'er 3}
The Books you have, before you call for more,
Ans. And those you have purloin'd, good Jack restore.
Resign some of those Cures you labour hard in, 3}
If you must spend whole Summers in your Garden,
Ans. Thy labours, Johnny, are not worth one Farthing.
Attend some one at least, and quit Glass-Nevin, 3}
Which will destroy your Credit, if you live in,
Ans. To Jack, no Credit ever yet was given,

·There are two Lines here omitted, which reflected only on a Lady of extraordinary Abilities and Virtue, and on whom the following Epigram was Written by Dr. S──t.* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *
Quickly do this, or you may some Provoke,
To say you mean to fleece, not feed the Flock,

l.hi: Ans. So to conclude, the Poet is a Block──────head.

lg.l: Ans. Good Reader, if he's near, secure your Pock──et.
